div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER. ESTABLISHED 1880. Editor and Manager - R. SNELLEN. Price ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
SATURDAY, MAY 18, 1907.
THE EGYPTIAN NATIONALISTS AND TURKEY.
div.p: 1905 and the vigorous outburst of pro-Turkish sentiment which preceded it. At the time it was the fashion to describe this emeute as utterly unconnected with political questions, to ascribe its origin to the presence of nume rons criminals of all nationalities in Alexandria and to declare that the Nationalist Press and party were absolutely free from blame. Next came the frontier trouble during the early stages of which the Nationalist Press maintained an attitude, which, if decidedly friendly to Turkey, was at all events free from any very violent partisanship. But in March, when the dispute between the Governments involved had reached a more advanced stage, the Turkish High Commissioner in Egypt realised that that Press which had previously supported the Ottoman Empire through good and evil might now become his mouth-pieoe.

IIow far these newspapers were committed to a Pau-lslamic policy we do hot know. They had undoubtedly lent their aid to the Pan- Islamic party at Constantinople in the past, they had described the real, or more often the imaginary, suffering of Moslems under foreign rule, and at that, time they hud not realised that the European Radical views Turkey with a certain suspicion, to use the mildest term. At all events they played up well to their Ottoman partners lead and their attitude provoked considerable nervousness both in the Capital and in Alexandria, where a certain amount of alarm had ulready been caused by the riots of 1905.

We need not go into details concerning the attitude of the various Nationalist organs during the later days of jhe crisis.''Al Unnna," whose Editor recently served a term in gaol, discovered that the Ottoman Army—undeterred by the fact that H.I.M. the Sultan could not be said to command the seas—had been in some mysterious way transported to Alex i/ndria. Another organ discovered that the Egyptian troops—ns Moslems—could not engage in battle with the armies of the Sultan. "Al licwa'' learnt from the Ghazithat Turkey had an excellent army of 8(H),000 men, 80,000 of whom were awaiting the call to invade Egypt between Aleppo and Ma'An. "Al Minbar" discovered virtues hitherto undiscemed by man in the Ottoman Government. In a word the journalistic cohorts mobilised rapidly and carried on a brisk campaign till the sudden discovery by- Turkey that England was uot to be bluffed out of the Sinai and that the Ottoman armies were in no condition to invade Egypt.

Then came the reaction : the discovery that thegoodRadicalsonwhom the Nationalist party had counted were disinclined to retire befoio the Sultan's menaces were scandalised (with the exception of the ineffable Mr. Blunt) at the rapprochement of Egyptian Nationalists and Turk. A most unpleasant state of affairs! But our friends put a bold face on the Ujatter'f They disavowed their quondam,allies, and—as those ladies, who, after a somewhat deplorable past, strive by good works to return to.the society which has for long cut them—so our Nationalists declared that Turkish method did hot please them, that they desired a free and independent Egypt and that they had never intended to help the Turks to seize the Sinai Peninsula, The lines quoted at the beginning ot our article are quoted from ajKipulnr song, of which there are many versions. The heroinedeafHbea heri.own' cozness—twist will and will not, ami the ruther forward conduct of her admirer on Are to snatch a kiss. May we point out that the following version is a very fair description of the attitude of the extreme Egyptian Nationalists towards the Ottoman Empire.
Fa hatte xlu— ala khattc
Fa'dila—ahil eedak—hat eedak J Iiuiiifee ya wid !
At present we are in the 't^il eedak' stage- how soon will jt be before 'liatte eedak' will describe ths^ attitude of our Nationalist agitators towards the Commander of the Faithful?
Fa lintte etilu—'ala oede.
Fa 'uttilu—shil eedak — butt vt-.Uk,
Oum bfinni ya wad;

In the whole history of the frontier incident of 1906, nothing was more interesting that the attitude of a section of the Nationalist Press, and almost equally interesting are the attempts now made by tliat section to explain away that attitude. Our renders will remember the riot which occurred at Alexandria in November

The Press of Egypt.

According to returns just published, there were on the 31st December 1906, 137 journals pahVlied in Egypt, 89 of which appear at Cairo, 38 at Alexandria, 5 at Port Said, 3 at Tautali. 1 at Assiout, and 1 at Miniea. Of the 89 political, and financial journals. 4.7 are Europeans, Hit vernacular, and 9 in other Oriental languages. There are 2 Arabic historical journals, 4 comic papers (of which 2 vernacular), 16 literary, scientific, and industrial reviews, 8 judicial reviews, 2 medical reviews, 13 religious papers, 2 ladies' papers and 1 masonic paper.

Hellonio Assize Court

The Greek Consulate at Alexandria was open up to 2 o'clock this morning, at which hour judgment was pronounced in the case of Cottas accused of complicity in the murder, of a Greek lady and her servant in the village of Kl-Fahn.

The murderer, n native, was sentenced to death,and executed last year. It was only after his execution thnt the villagers denounced I'ottas to'the policejts an accomplice in the murder.- Cottas was at once arrested and sent io Alexandria and his trial began on Tuesday last. The Court refused to believe the. native withneases and acquitted the accused.

M. S. can possibly pay. The C. M. S. comittee fully recognize ue of securing a site and erecting these own buildings, hut the financial condi- ii..ii of the socioty is so grave, and the deficit heavy, that they cannot authorize their making 'a special appeal fur funds to provide tlc-in with premises ihtffi- require until nfte ila end of the year, when the accounts are made up, and they are agreeable to consider the mailer again,

div.head: THE MARIOUT RAILWAY-
div.p: The new circular running shed at Mex for the locomotives of the the Khedive's railway to Mariout lms just been finished. The running shed is the most modern of its kind in Egypt and accommodates twelve locomotives. Each pit lms two chimneys and consequently it does not matter which way the locomotive goes over the pit. The running shed is quite complete except for a few details in the roof. The new steel bridge, which his Highness has erected over the Mex channel from Lake Mareotis, will be finished in a few weeks', time, The temporary wooden bridge over which the line ran will then be taken away.

div.p: The Moss liner S.S. Menes now on berth will sail on or about Sunday, 19th May, to be followed by S.S Seti. The Moss liner Anmsis arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning.

div.head: BRITISH AGENT'S RECEPTION.
SPEECHES OF KHEDIVE AND SIR E. GORST.
div.p: The following is the text of Sir Eldon Goret's speech to the Khedive on the occasion of the presentation of the exequatur at Ras-el-Tin Palace the King, my august Sovereign, having been graciously pleased to appoint me his representative in Egypt, I have the honour to deliver to your Highness a letter frpm His Majesty's Principal Secretory of State for Foreign Affairs, accrediting me in that character. In accordance with the instructions which I have received from his Majesty, I shall be zealous in maintaining those friendly relations which have so -tong happily subsisted between Great Britain aha Egypt, and I feel confident that 1 shall receive from your Highness every a.-4(fStance and facility to enable me to execute the duties which Iris Majesty has been graciously pleased to entrust to uije. The kindness which yonr»Highness 1ms abyars- displayed towards njp, during the lnapy years when I bud tho honour to be in yontdlighness's service, and thd great interest which 1 have never ceased to take in the welfare and prosperity of Egypt and its inliabir tants, have caused me to feef special gratification at having been selected by his Majesty the King as his Agent and Consul-General in the country over which your Highness rules. The Khedive replied in French as follows:— Mofisienr le Ministre, Je suis ttos heurenx de vous souhaiter la bienvenno en votre quality de reprdsentant de S. M. Britaimiqne en Egypte. Je me fdlicite du choir de S. M. le Roi, Votre Auguste Souverain, et j'y trouve une nonvelle preuve le Son dtfsir de voir se conso- lider de plus en plus les liens amicanx tablis entre l'Angleterre et l'Egypte. Im'est tres agrdable, de vous entendre me mppeler les anuses jiendant lesqnelles vous nvez collaboto au ildveloppeiuent de mon pays d'nne nmnicre si agrdnble. Le grand in tore t quo vous n'avez eessd de prcijdre aussi au hien ctre de sea habitants m'est un sftr gnrant qu'une entente ri-gnera entre nous. Soyez done convaincu, Mr. le Ministre, que vous trouverez toujours auprc.s de moi le plus loyal concours. Je vous prie d'en transmettre I'assurunoe 5 S. M. le Roi avec l'exprcssion de Jim tres vive gratitude pour les sentiments de haute bienveillance dont il daigne m'honorer et qni me toiichent profondihiieiit.

div.head: DEATH OF MR SYDNEY CARVER-
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Mr. Sydney H. Carver, of the firm of Messrs. Carvor Brothers and Company Limited, who died at Liverpool yesterday. The telegram was received at Alexandria today at the moment of our going to press.

div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS.
LORD CROMER IN LONDON.
div.p: The Coptic organ, "Al Watan," says : Nothing can be more ridiculous or more absurd than the position of those who wish to lead the public to the belief that Lord Cromer was forced by political reasons to quit his post on the Nile. They had pictured Sir Henry Cumphell- Banneriimnu as differing with Lord Cromer Slid criticising his policy, thus necessitating the withdrawal of the great Pro-Consul from Egypt. Time and again their fallacies were torn to tatters by the simple logic of "Al- Watan" and by the testimony of events, lmt they doggedly held to their affected belief and rejoiced over the "dismissal" of. Egypt's best friend. What will they say on reading the news of Lord Cromer's reception in Iiondnu ? A dismissed official is not usually met at the station by princes and ministers past and present, nor is he asked to proceed direct from the station to the pnlace to receive thenmrk of the highest favour and distinction. Yet Lord Cromer has been received with all this ceremony and this respect, and his return was made the occasion fur official and national recognition of his greut and invaluable services to Egypt and the British Empire. If Mustafa Kamel and his friends insist after all this on saying that Lord Cromer was sacrificed for their sake we can only say that no further arguments should lie expended in vain.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
LAND PRICES.
div.p: Although the depression is universal in the share markets, the price of land at Alexandria lias not been affected to a like degree. The depression is solely confined to suburban building land. For example, a few months ago land was bought at the Bains Cleopatre district of Ibrnhiinieh, on the main mad, at P.T. 150 per pic.The same land has recently changed liands at P.T. 85 per pic. In Alexandria itself the price of land exhibits great firmness. At Cairo also land values keep firm. Agricultural land, on the contrary, is still booming. For example the Union Foncieresold some laud a few weeks ago at L.E. 160 per feddan, which the company had purchased eighteen months ago for L.E. 52 per feddau. A Cairo correspondent writes :— There is a considerable lull at Cairo in land matters at present, even in the best quarters, chiefly due to the tightness of the money market. In tin's connection it is a very long time since*there bus been such a tightness of funds, especially ns there is no lack of money in the country. It might he almost said thnt the Banks are carrying their caiOion to extremes and Tio official announcement has appeared so far showing what the Banks will do to ease the situation, although there is a general sense of greater safety and things are gradually settling down to a firm, nnd,letitbe hoped, solid basis. It is worthy of note that there has been no sort of panic or have any astonishing failures been reported which, as a matter of fact, points to the view that there is a general move in the direction of solidity, as it is well known that several tottering, concerns have been bolstered up to save the situation. There is plenty of evidence to show, however, that the bulk of the wealth of the country still lies in the hands of the natives, both city and country dwellers; and it has been proved thnt their methods are very conservative. Many would be very much astonished to know the actual fortunes of some of the commercial native families in Cairo and the amount of property they hold. Fortunately there ure many factors to ensure Egypt gradually finding a bed rock level and the increasing spirit of confidence generally justifies this assertion.

div.head: CAIRO PALACE THEATRE. LIMITED.

In a recent issue we stated that a hitch luid occurred in the negotiations between the promoters of the above concern, which was registered last month in London with tho object of erecting a high class music hall and variety theatre on the site of the Hnmmnm in the Halim square, and the Socidto5 Bclge-Egyptienno de 1'RsWkieh, who own the projierty, on account of the expiration of the original option before payment of the stipulated deposit We understand that the terms of the agreement included a twenty years' lease. The promoters have now been granted an extension of their option to the 15th June and it is to he hoped that they will succeed in finding the necessary capital by that time lor securing the site, which is of 3750 square metres. It is intended, wo understand, to erect, besides tho music hall, a high class restaurant with a club on the upper floor, the total cost lieing estimated at something like £60,000. The situation lieing an ideal one, there is no doubt that the venture will prove a great success.
THE "EGYPTIAN STANDARD"
THE EDITOR'S NEW BOOK.
div.p: Mr. Charles Rudy, the Editor of the "Egyptian Standard," has written a I took which has for its subject the Cathedrals' of Northern Spain. The "Atbemeum" in a criticism of the work concludes :— Errors of lunguage and interpretation abound. We find the English "see" repeatedly used for cathedral, a* if it were the equivalent of the Sjmnish "seo." "Castro," the common SjMinisli for a fortified camp, is explained to mean "a druid place of worship '' ; and "Compostela" (persistently misspelt) denied its natural derivation from .Income A|iostol in favour of the long-abandoned "field of stars." Mr. Rudy's method of dealing with the great legends of early Siwuiish history is in no better taste than his jiatronizing reference to the "intelligence" of the late Mr. Street; and the attempts at wit with which he has seen fit to intersperse his anecdotes of heroes and martyrs are not inspiriting. The manner of the liook does nothing to atone for defects in its matter. Mr. Rudy writes of "ogival marvels" and "Islam principles" ; he says "the rosace is substituted by a three-lohed window" and "the origin....is ignored," when lie means that the window was substituted for the rosace, and that the origin is unknown. Page after page of his work is disfigured by the excessive introduction of French words. We read of "a rriard impression" and "an effect re/iautte" by gilded columns.

div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondants, but we wish in spirit to fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits-free discussion.

div.head: THE CROMER MEMORIAL
A CRITICISM.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" Sir, — May I, as a very small and humble member of the community in this town, be allowed to make a suggestion, on the eve of the subscription list - being opened . of the Cromer memorial Fund. Would it not be well to ask the following questions] Are we choosing the right-form that the memorial should take ] Is it one which I.ord Cromer himself would care for most 7 Is it entirely popular 'in the town that is anxious to commemorate June. In each case I venture to reply in the negative, and, furthermore, would make so bold as to say that not only is the idea and suggestion of collecting funds for a consumptive hospital highly unpopular generally, but there is also a very strong existing under-current of feeling that this particular movement has been forced against their will on the community at large, by a certain few, who are more or less interested only in one pet charity so to speak, they forgetting, the while, that before Lord Cromer's departure from this country was ever anticipated, the Tuberculosis League had already decided they would be able to build a small sanatorium before the end of year sufficiently large to meet, the need of patients here—the idea merely being to be able to isolate certain persons in advanced stages of the disease and thus protect their families from the risk of infection. A large hospital of this kind, I believe 1 am correct in asserting, would be inadvisable and, in fact, detrimental to the well-being of the .town. Of necessity it would mean that its patients would be drawn, not only from the town itself, but from the entire Levant, and I would venture to suppose onr desire should be rather to try and stamp out the disease than invite and facilitate those suffering from it to lie brought here to die in our midst. The fete held at San Stefano last Sunday is spoken of ns linving been a great financial success, and there were l>eforehand existing funds.T therefore the wherewithal must be forthcoming, and those mainly interested in the Tuberculosis League can hnvo their sanatorium of a size which would be quite suited to the demands. Has no person ever thought of suggesting that the present existing irintemity hospital might lie enlarged and placed on a proper basis in this town 7 Surely this work is one that appeals to ever)- nationality and benefits each as well 7 Most of all that is to be said in favour of this suggestion is that there is little donbt that not. only Ijord Cromer, blit his wife, who has taken so keen an interest in the welfare of women and children in this country, would prefer infinitely that the memorial should take this form than most others. A splendid opening for the further good of the town lie® ahead'in this work, for the present little hospital is doing sound and good work by benefiting so many poor women, and not only them, hut, their children in some few cases, as a small residential crOche was o]>ened a year ago, where women who have to work can leave their infants for the early months. If this institution could he re-organised and placed on a sound financial basis it could afford to keep two district nurses or midwives for the native women and thus commence a work which is also a real need at the present moment A further immense advantage in choosing this charity, as a fitting form of memorial which is at this moment needing everyone's interest and support, would be that a good cause already in existence would he benefited and the formation of yet another new charity would be obviated, for flint already there are too many all will agree with me. Thanking you for allowing me space to give vent to my feelings on this subject at the present moment.- remain. AN ANXIOUS SPECTATOR. Alexandria, May 15.-

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Yesterday Prince Henry of Prussia and his suite arrived at Port Said by the Austrian S.S. Salzburg from Jaffa. The Prince left Port Said in the evening by the German East African liner Burger ineister.

The Khedive has conferred the Medjidieh; third class, on My. Nicole, Danish Vice Consul at Cairo. M. Angelopoulo, Chancellor and Secretary to the Danish Consulate at Cairo, has been appointed Chevalier of the same order.
Princess Nazli Hanem and suite left Alexandria yesterday by the Florio-Rubattigo steamer. Her Highness is proceeding to Tunis to meet, her husband, Said Klmlil Abou Hogeb.
Mahmoud Pasha Sidki, Governor of Cairo, will take three and a half months' leave of absence dating from June 22.
Mr. Simpson, formerly manager of 'the National Bank at Fayoum, has been transferred to Port Said, where he assumes, his now duties on Tuesday.
Mr. Russell Barrett has left Cairo for England, where he will pass the summer.

div.head:
DOCK RIOTS IN BELFAST.
TROOPS CALLED OUT.

div.p: Riots have occurred in connection with a strike of clock labourers at Belfast. The police made baton charges. Troops are posted at the docks provided with ball cartridges. (Reuter)

div.head:
JAPAN IN MANCHURIA.
OPEN DOOR POLICY.

div.p: The "Times" correspondent at Peking draws attention to the .IajMine.se negation in practice of the policy of the "open-door and cijual .opportunity in Manchuria, and to the Japanese wholesale employment of imitated British foreign trade-marks, also to breaches of copyright. He adds that these questions are impairing the good feeling existing between the two peoples. (Reuter)

div.head:
TERRORISM AT LODZ.
BRUTALITY OF TROOPS.

div.p: Terrorist robberies are taking jtlnce through out the country almost daily. A band attacked a mail-van at Lodz, killing or wounding -1 Cossacks and policemen and escaping with 2,000 roubles. A Cossack patrol arrived n/moment later and dashing into an acIjhceiit-eotton mill, shot down workmen indiscriminately, killing 15 and wounding over 30 of them. A band to-day attacked a railway office at Warsaw. They killed or wounded G soldiers guarding it and escaped with 10,(MM) roubles. The soldiers, returning their assaillants' lire, killed or wounded 7 customers. Both affairs took place in Urn centre of the city in broad daylight v (Reuter) ST. PETERSBURG, May 17. (Later). Altogether 22 persons have been killed and 48 wounded at Lodz. (Reuter) LODZ, May 17. The troops, following a gang who hud robbed a postal van, searched a factory and killed twenty workmen on duty. Many others were wounded. (Hava*)

div.head:
EDUCATION IN RUSSIA.
CHURCH AND STATE

div.p: While discussing the education question the Duma ejected three deputies of the right for using violent language. The commission rejected a motion from the left for the separation of Church and State. (Havas)
M. Nelidoff, Ambassador at Paris, has been appointed first Russian delegate at the Hague Conference. He will probably he elected President. (Renter)

Sir E. Grey's statement with reference to the Congo Free State has created much uneasiness in Belgium. The "Gazette ile Bruxelles'' says that his 'menacing declaration disagreeably recalls the first sjieeches in the British Parliament jerior to the Transvaal war. (Rented)
All the British residents of Marrakesh have reached Safti. Some Europeans are still missing. (Reuter)

div.head: PORT SUDAN.
DEVELOPMENT OF TRADE.
MR. HOHLER'S REPORT.
THE LEASE SYSTEM.
div.p: Next, the town itself is entirely unprepared for the reception of visitors. The Sudan Government have, will a view to preventing speculation, invited1 tenders for land on a lease system, but the conditions are onerous and exacting. The plots of land are divided into three classes in the town, while there is a special class on the custom-house side of the water, .whore warehouses will be built. The minimum yearly rent demanded for a first class plot is from 100% to 55% for an average second class plot 30% for a third class plot 51. The warehouse sites must pay 16/. to 18/. In addition, a premium is demanded The lease is for 80 years. Buildings must be erected within four years on first class plots of a value of 2,000/ ; on second class, within three, years,, of 800/, Ac. In addition, lessees will; be liable to rates and taxes, conservancy, lighting and water taxes, house tax, etc. Tho streets are to be paved, and sido walks made, tho cost of which is to bo borne by the lessees ; the cost is estimated to bo equivalent to about three or four years'rent. The houses are to bo built in nccordnnco with Sudan Government regulations, and no buildings are. to erected except those originally approved, and no structual alterations and additions are to bo made without tho Government approval in , writing. All buildings nre to be kept in a fair state of repair, external and internal. At present tho inhabitants are living in wooden shanties which they have been allowed to erect on the understanding that they are liable to bo removed at threX days' notice. One firm, to avoid this insecurity, has established itself well outside the piesent limits of the town, ns it is concerned with heavy machinery, which could not possibly be moved within the time limit—and not at all without inflicting great damage on the firm No provision is yet made for large plots such as would be necessary for workshops, Ac.- But this unfortunate state of things will doubtlessly be ameliorated life long

div.head: HOTEL WANTED.
div.p: As yet no hotel has boon built, and there is no accommodation whatsoever for the visitor. Agents travelling for firms would have to bring their tents with them, and so should those who intend to go by this route to Khartoum, fur if their ship is quarantined, THIS often happens they may have to wait two days for the train Some of the junior employees of the Government have great difficulty in obtaining lodgings. I have heard of cases where a clerk receiving 51. month has to pay 1/. a month for a room-

div.head: OPENING FOR BRITISH TRADE.
div.p: The next point to lie dealt openings for British trade.

The increased import of tea is worth noting. Competition might be made with Austria- Hungary in supplying cheap furniture of almost, all kinds—cupboards, bentwood chairs, tables, etc.—and also in cheap white collars, cotton vests, cotton shirts.There would lie no difficulty in ascertaining precisely the kind which the natives prefer.

There is one most important point, and this applies to all trade with ibis part of the world. Prices should lie quoted.. If., and measures should lie given in the measures of the country. If this cannot be done, Thev should lit least lie given in the metric scale.

There is an excellent opening for ironware, light girders for building in particular. These arc at present supplied from Belgium, They are considerably lighter and much cheaper than those of British make, and qre apparently strong enough for the .work they have to do. I am assured that life is no reason whatever why British manufacturers could not produce these girders. The demand for them will la- very considerable when the land tenure epics- the is settled and the building of the town commences in next. Germany supplies a quantity of house fittings, locks, door handles, clasps for Frrench doors, A-c., also onamelware of a cheap quality. Here again there is an opening. I am told there is a good accessibility of selling Jacking glasses and razors to the native inhabitants of this region ; the razors ought to be of a fairly good quality. An agent would easily be able to judge whether this information is cotract.

With regard to cotton goods, a curious case occurred recently, when* steamer was wrecked oft Sunk in and the cargo mainly white sliasli and cotton dyed with large bright patterns, jettisoned ; it was salved, ! taken to the town, and sold by auction, and though damaged by water it fetched prices higher than those prevailing in the market for similar hut undamaged goods.
As soon as the wharves and coal lifts are ready for use there should be a good opening for the coal trade,
. The demand for coal, both for Government and private use, is increasing every day with the expansion of railways, irrigation, works, Nile steamer lines, &c.
(To be continued)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Captain Herbert Dixon, 6th Inniskilling Dragoons (brother of Sir T. Dixon, Bart, who was latterly doing duty with the Dojiot Squadron at Ballincollig, has been placed on half pay owing to his health. His many friends will wish Kim a speedy recovery to his wonted state of health.
Lieutenant C-A.L Irvine, 2nd Battalion King's On Scottish Borderers, Uts also gone on half-pay for a similar reason. This will be learned with regret by all ranks of the 2nd Battalion at Cairo.
Second Lieutenant D. Hanly has been ap- pitinted to the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, from Sandhurst, and will join the 2nd Battalion at Cairo.

The Royal Indian Mail steamship Northbrook which is due to leave Southampton on the 25th May, brings out a number of officers and various details for regiments and battalions in India via Port Said and Suez.

The Army Council seems to he a hit undecided in doing anything about the introduction of the new automatic gun, as the plan for the selection of some of the. types already before it gets no "forrader." So long age as tho issue of the present short rifle, it was understood that it was only to lie a stop gaji till the adoption'of an automatic rifle.

A return just issued ns a parliamentary jiaper, shews that the number of commissions from the ranks last year was 57 in all—as compared with 42 the previous year, 58 in 1904, G5 in 1903, 99 in 1902, 116 in 1901, I9G in 1900, and 109 in 1899, the great increase in the latter figures being due to the Boer War. The commissions given last year were divided Into 10 second lieutenancies in the infantry and A.S.G., -and 7 in the Royal Artillery ; 4 quarter navy ships in the cavalry, 12 in the infantry, 7 in the A.S.C., and 8 in the Army Ordnance, and 2 riding-masters' commissions in the cavalry.

Lieutenant J. F. Mucky, King's Own Scottish -Borderers, presently serving as a subaltern in the Northern Nigeria Regiment, has been specially prompted cajttain into the Hampshire Regiment. Captain Muckay got his commission in the K.O.S.B. in 1901, after spending nearly seven years in the ranks of the Gordon Highlanders. Htj was with the Gordons in the North West Frontier Exjiedition, 1897-98 medal with clasps) and again with them in the South African war, and subsequently as an officer of the Borderers, and won the V.t'. at the action of Crow's Nest Hill, near Johannesburg,.by carrying succour to several wound oil soldiers under a very heavy fire. It is given t i very few to win a commission and tho little bronze cross, for valour in one campaign.

The "muzzling order" of the Army Council is being carried out with a vengeance, even (In- officers and men of the Militia and the Imjieriul Yeomanry being now forhiddep to act as Press correspondents, with any army in the field, or at foreign nmiuiuvre*, or to publish or communicate eithordirectlyorindireotlv, any military information to the Press without the express permission of the Army Council This no doubt in connection with the scathing criticisms which have come from all ranks of all arms on the schemes of Haldane and Co.

Of the many schemes that have been evolved for the protection of British commerce and interests in war time over the great ocean highway between the Sue?. Canal and Singapore —u highway at present very inadequately looked after by the greatly weakened East Indies Squadron—is one which advocates tho formation of an Indian Fleet, officered by offices of the Royal Navy, and largely manned by native crows. The composition of the suggested Fleet is—five first class armoured cruisers, four in commission, and one in reserve at Bomliuy, fifteen destroyers of the ocean going type, and a proportion of gunlrouts, topedo boats, etc. The prt bable cost of each cruiser would be £1,500,000, and of the destroyers about £150,000 each. Instead of being constructed like the "general service" ship, in which the handyman -is half frozen nmidst the Jpgs of Newfoundland, or half roasted "up the Gulf', it is pointed out that these cruisers could be built in a style suitable for the torrid zone, and wijh an eye to the intricacies of carfte. If we err not, the sea-board population of India gave hardy sailors to the navy in the early period of the British occupation) and still more recently Lascars did duty aboard ship. Such a fleet could not only protect the highway eastwards, but also give assistance in China and Australian waters. Of course, it is too much to expect that the jtresent Government, which is apparently more bent on disintegrating the Empire than building it up, to move in sutjr a matter. The scheme has its weak points, but it has also its strong ones, and is well worthy of the consideration of the home and Indian Governments.

div.head: STRICTER AND KIDNEY DISEASE.
HOW BEER AFFECTED THE KIDNEYS.
CURED 2 YEARS Ago — STILL WELL TO-DAY.
div.p: 55, Brighton Place, Hamjlton Square, Sheen Lane, Mortlake,

,, London, England. For nearly 19 years I suffered from stricture and kidney disease, and many a time have I laid on the bedroom floor writhing in agony. Twee 1 have been in bosjiital and undergone (Iterations for the stricture. Never, ns long ns I live, shall 1 forget what I went through then. The doctors said I could not live another three months, yet I can truly say that, although two years have passed since then, I was never better in my life than 1 am to-day.

My illness came on in this way : One day at my work I strained my back, and afterwards I suffered from severe pains justover where the kidneys are, especially when 1 stood. 1 could not sleep well at nights, and there were distressing urinary disorders. I was miserable and out of sorts, and although the doctor did all he could for me, I got worse instead of better, if I had a glass of lieer it irritated my kidneys so much that I had to keep to my bed for a week, hut since using Doan's Backache Kidney Pills I can enjoy my glass without feeling a bit the worse for it.

It wasn't until I lmd finished the fourth box of Doan's Pills that they seemed to Ire doing me any good, hut I persisted with the medicine, and with the fifth box there was 'a decidedly freer notion of the bladder. No other medicine had ever helped me at all, and you can imagine how delighted 1 was at this relief. For six months I continued with Doan's Backache Kidney Pills, and then l was entirely cured of the stricture and kidney disease. From that day to this there hasn't been any sign of the old complaints returning.
My suffering and my cure are well-known to hundreds of men f have worked with in London, and I am sure that had I not used Doan's Backache Kidney Pills when I did, I should never have lived.

Every applicant for Ordinary Shares will be entitled to apply for and receive an allotment of one Founder's Share for every fifty Ordinary Shares allotted to him. Ttys Prospectus has been fit with the Registrar of Joint Stoclk Compares. The Subscription List will open on the 22nd day of' Tuesday 1907, and close on or before the 23rd day of May 1907.
The Cairo Exchange Limited. (Incorporated under the Companies Acts 1862 to 1900).
Divided into 123,750 Ordinary Shares of £1 each, and 25,000 Founders Shares of One Shilling each.

The Ordinary Shares are entitled In receive out of the divisible profits «f each year after providing for reserve and for the rein ineration of the Managing Director a preferential dividend at the rate, of Five per cent. The balance of such profits after providing for the remuneration of the Directors as hereunder mentioned will be attributed as to tit) per cent, thereof to the Ordinary Shares and as to 40 per ce t, thereof to the Founders Shares. The Fourniers Shares are also entitled to 40 per cent of the surplus assets which in the winding up of the Company shall remain after repayment of Capital No underwriting Commission has been or will he uaid. 98,750 Ordinary Shares are now offered for subscription at par together with the corresponding number of Founders Shares in the proportion stated above. The Ordinary Shares are payable as follows : 2/6 per Share on Application 2 6 per 8hare on Allotment And the balance in calls not exceeding per Share, the first call not to be made before the expiration of four months from the date of issue.
The Founders Shares are payable In full on Aplication.
No allotment of less than 50 Ordinary Shares will be made to any one Subscriber.

div.head: PROSPECTUS.
div.p: This Company has been formed with the objects set forth in its Memorandum of Association and in particular for the purpose of acquiring as a going concern the business of Stockbrokers and Agents de Change heretofore carried on by Mr Percy Wyfold Stoat in partnership with the late Mr. Ernest Charles Hogg under the style of Ilogg and Stout
Under the Contract below mentioned the business of the Firm will be taken over- by the Company as from the 2nd day of Apiil 1907 (the date of the death of Mr.IIogg)
from which date the whole of the Firm's assets will l»e acquired and its liabilities as

sumed by the Company. The price to be paid for the Goodwill of tho business is £25,000 which will be satisfied by the allotment to Mr Percy Wyfohl Stout, tho surviving partner in the Firm, of 25,000 Ordinary Shares credited as fully paid.

The Company will acquire the assets of the Firm including all cash in hand stocks shares and securities bookdebts contracts in course of execution leasehold premises and furniture ami effects in consideration of the payment in cash to Mr. Percy Wyfold Stout of the sum of £.E.29,480 that being the amount certified by Mr. Kerr,
Chartered Accountant, as the fair value of the excess of the assets over liabilities as on
the 2nd April 1907.
Mr. Percy Wyfold Stout lias agreed to act as Managing Director of tho Company for a period of five years upon the terms of the Contracts below mentioned.

Mr. Stout has agreed to pay all the preliminary expenses of forming and floating the Company down to, hut not including, the first general allotment of Ordinary Shares to the public, such preliminary expenses being estimated at £2,000—. Ho has also guaranteed the subscription of 50,000 Ordinary Shares now offered in consideration of his having the right at any time prior to the 31st December 1907 to call lor the allotment to him at par of 14,500 Founders Shares and for the allotment at par either to himself or his nominees of the additional number of 4,425 Founders Shares.

Col. Gordon and Mr. Russell, the other Directors of the Company arc subscribing for and will each be allotted at par 400 Founders' Shares. Each of them has also sub- underwritten 2,000 Ordinary Shares in consideration of the right to subscribe for 120 ad ditional Founders' Shares.
The Minimum subscription on which the Directors may proceed- to allotment is 25 per cent of the shares offered.
The following Contracts have been entered into :

A Contract dated the 9th May 1907 lietween the Vendor, Percy Wyfold Stout, carrying on business as a Stockbroker at Cairo under the style nr firm of Hogg Stout of the one part, and the Company of the other part, being the Contract for Sale.
A Contract dated the 9th May 1907, between the Company of the one part, and the said Percy Wyfold Stout of the other part, lieing a Contract for the employment of the latter as Managing Director.
This Contract contains the following provisions :

The said Percy Wyfold Stout (hereinafter called the Managing Director) shall he entitled to hold office as Managing Director of the Company for a term of five years from the time when the Company shall become entitled to commence business.
The Managing Director whilst holding such ollicft shall perform the duties anil exercise the powers which from time to time may be assigned to or vested in him by the Directors ot the Company.
So long as the Manuging Director shall hold such office, no other Director or Directors of the Compuny shall be appointed without the consent of such Managing Director.

4 The Managing Director whilst holding such office shall w«JF and faithfully serve the Company and use liis best endeavours to promote the interests thereof. Ho shall bo entitled to four consecutive calendar months'leave of absence in every year at a time convenient to him.

The Managing Director whilst holding such ofiiee shall hold his Membership of the Cairo Bourse for the benefit of the Company, and shall use his best endeavours to continue such Membership, and shall not operate on the said Bourse except on behalf of the Company.

The Managing Director whilst holding such office shall be paid as remuneration for his servjpes a fixed salary at the rate ofr£ 1/500 pet annum payable monthly, and in addition thereto shall be entitled to receive in resp'hct 'of every year such sum (not exceeding £5,(KM)) as shall be equivalent toAwo and a half |teV cent of the profits of the Company made during the financial year or Other, period comprised in tho accounts snbmittedto the Ordinary General Meeting in each year and of any profits carried forward from past years. The Managing Director whilst holding.such office shall not he entitled to participate in the remuneration allowed by the Articles of Association to the Directors of the Cdmpany.
. 3. A Contract dated the 9th May 1907'made between the said Percy Wyfold Stout of
the dnP part and the Company of the other part being the Contract guaranteeing the subscription of tne Ordinary Shares now offered )
The following are extracts from the Company's Articles of Association.

. 85. The qualification of a Director sha'l be the holding of Ordinary Shares of the Company to the nominal value of £500. A first Director may act before acquiring his inaguration, bat shall in any case acquire the same within one month from In Ap- poiotment, and unless he shall do so he shall lie deemed to liaye agreed to take the Mid shares flfom the Company and the same shall be forthwith allotted to him accordingly

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: Alexandria Water Company LTD.
COLD STORAGE ROOMS
div.p: The Alexandria Water Company Ltd. beg to bring to the public notice the fact that in addition to its now and well equipped Ice Factory at Porto Rosette, it, has also constructed 6 cold storage rooms suitable for the storage of moat, groceries, game, and other perishable articles. The rooms have a total area of about 50 square meters dnd can easily be extended if there proves to be sufficient demand. The whole installation is very complete and has been constructed on the best and most modern lines. Full particulars and conditions as to the letting of these rooms will be given on application. H.R.C. BLAGDEN 30254-6-6. Manager.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
